justification: The article explains that rats “progressively decreased responding on the lever when contingency degradation had occurred,” presenting the contingency-degradation procedure as the assay for whether actions are under goal-directed control.

Throughout the review, impairments or intact performance on the “instrumental outcome devaluation task” are used to judge whether animals rely on outcome value, showing this procedure is the standard measure of goal-directed choice.

Figure 1B and accompanying text describe switching the outcomes of two actions in an “outcome identity reversal” and later testing behaviour, identifying this protocol as the measure of an animal’s ability to update action-outcome identity mappings.

Section V states that “A number of studies have used set-shifting tasks assessing aspects of behavioural flexibility in rodents (Birrell & Brown 2000),” indicating this paradigm is the behavioural instrument for measuring cognitive flexibility.
